The Common Application ApplyTexas Apply Coalition on SCOIR Transfer Update Form (For students who have previously applied to SMU within the last two years but did not enroll or withdrew enrollment before the 12th day of classes.) Step 3: Review and complete the application checklist. Complete your application on time - check the application deadlines Pay $60 nonrefundable application fee* Submit official college transcripts from all previously attended colleges or universities Applicants who have completed international coursework must also submit a professional evaluationthat shows the US equivalence for each educational credential and the credit and grade equivalents for university-level courses. This is often called a Course-by-Course evaluation. Submit an official high school transcript that includes a graduation date. If the transcript is not in English, it will need to be translated. Submit Official TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo English Test (DET) results InitialView interview* (highly encouraged if English is not the applicant's first language, but not required) Submit official SAT or ACT scores (optional) Review audition and portfolio requirements (students applying for Dance, Music, Theatre, Art, or Film) Step 4: Submit your application materials. Please submit your application online. Supporting documentscan be sent via email to ugadmission@smu.edu. We recommend that transcripts be sent electronically to SMU. If your school does not send electronic transcripts, they can be mailed to the following address: Mailing Address SMU Office of Undergraduate Admission PO Box 750181 Dallas TX 75275 Physical Address (for FedEx, UPS, and DHL shipments): Laura Lee Blanton Building 6185 Airline Road Dallas TX 75205 Please be sure that you indicate your first, middle and last name as well as your date of birth when you email or mail application materials. If you physically mail your documents, we recommend that you keep a copy of all application forms for your records. We look forward to reviewing your application and getting to know you better. If you have questions, please contact the SMU Office of Undergraduate Admission where any of our transfer admission counselors are ready to help. Phone: 214-768-2058 Fax: 214-768-1083 Office Hours: 8:30 a.m.-5:00 p.m. Central Standard Time Step 5: Track Your Status Track the completion of your application in your personalized Status Page. You will receive an email with your login information within 48-72 hours after you submit your application. * You may pay online through the SMU Online Application, the Common Application, the Coalition for College Application, or the Apply Texas Application. If you are going to pay by check, make the check payable to SMU and mail to the mailing address above. Benefits of an SMU Education Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Apply Transfer Benefits of an SMU Education Benefits of an SMU Education Transfer Benefits of an SMU Education Transfer Scholarships Transfer Admission Application Process Transfer Dates and Deadlines Transfer Pathway Guides Transfer Equivalency Tool Meadows Auditions and Portfolios Transfer Forms and Applications International Transfer Students FAQs Congratulations on your admission to SMU! How Credits Transfer Partnership Programs Bold, curious and creative students achieve excellence at this world-class university with ambition, grit and confidence. Our students don’t just succeed; they thrive after graduation by becoming leaders within their fields. Below you will find facts on the unparalleled benefits of an education from SMU in Dallas, Texas. 93% of SMU graduates have jobs or are in graduate school within six months after graduation. The Dallas area is ranked second among the best places nationally for business and careers by Forbes 2019. SMU ranks in the top 7% of colleges with the highest-paid graduates, and the top 19% of Best Colleges Based on Salary potential, according to PayScale’s 2020-21 College Salary Reports. SMU is one of only 300 schools nationwide that are worth the investment, according to Forbes’ 2019 Best Value Colleges ranking, which is based on quality, net price, net debt, alumni earnings, timely graduation and access for low-income students. 90% of Lyle School of Engineering students complete at least one internship. Every year more than 1,000 Dallas-area businesses offer more than 4,400 internships to SMU students. 94% of Cox graduates were off the job market within three months of graduation at an average starting salary of nearly $66K per year. College Factual counts SMU alumni among the top 5% of highest-paid graduates across a range of fields including the physical and social sciences, computer and information sciences, the humanities, the visual and performing arts, and business, management and marketing. SMU's commitment to academic and creative scholarship in the vibrant economic and artistic powerhouse of Dallas supports our students' success. DFW is the No. 1 metro area for STEM jobs, according to an American Enterprise Institute study (2020). 98% of the Simmons School’s Applied Physiology and Sport Management grads are employed or are pursuing/have completed grad school with APSM-related degree. SMU ranks among the top 20% best national universities in the 2020 edition of U.S. News & World Report’s Best Colleges. SMU tied for No. 1 on the 2021 College Factual list of Highest Paid Music Graduates. Learn even more about information listed above and several of SMU’s resources by reviewing the content below. Transfer Admission Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Apply Transfer Transfer Admission Transfer Admission Transfer Benefits of an SMU Education Transfer Scholarships Transfer Admission Application Process Transfer Dates and Deadlines Transfer Pathway Guides Transfer Equivalency Tool Meadows Auditions and Portfolios Transfer Forms and Applications International Transfer Students FAQs Congratulations on your admission to SMU! How Credits Transfer Partnership Programs Please select what type of transfer student you will be: Traditional Transfer Students First-Year Transfer Students International Transfer Students Visiting (Non-Degree seeking) Students Former SMU Students (Readmission to SMU) Please note additional requirements for transfer students interested in the following areas: Performing and Visual Arts Business Majors Economics Majors Academic forgiveness: SMU allows you to dismiss course work taken 10 or more years prior to the term of admission from consideration in your application process as well as from inclusion in your transferable GPA and hours earned for transfer to SMU. × Traditional Transfer Students Traditional Transfer students are those students who will transfer in 30 or more transferable hours to SMU. The Admission Committee will focus on your college coursework and transferable GPA for admission. The Committee finds that students with a 2.70 transferable GPA or higher are the most competitive for admission. In the admission process for transfer students, we evaluate both the rigor of the college courses you've taken and the readiness for your intended major. We recommend taking all or some of the prerequisite courses for your intended major before transferring to SMU. All transfer students are required to complete college algebra or a college-level math course before transferring to SMU. If algebra I, geometry and algebra II were taken in high school and graduation was less than three years ago, this requirement is waived. We recommend that all transfer students complete an English composition course, a lab science course, a math course beyond college algebra and at least one course in your intended major before transferring. Close × First-Year Transfer Students First-year transfer students are those students who have fewer than 30 transferable hours or who have graduated from high school within the last calendar year. If three or more years have passed since your high school graduation, we highly recommend that you acquire 30 or more transferable hours before you transfer. All first-year transfer students will be automatically considered for first year academic-based scholarshipsbased on your high school academic performance, including high school GPA, curriculum, and SAT or ACT test score. In order to qualify for transfer scholarships you must complete at least half of the 50-hour requirement after your high school graduation. In addition to evaluating your college course work and transferable GPA, the Admission Committee will also review your high school curriculum, high school GPA and standardized test scores. Your official test scores will need to be submitted directly from College Board or the ACT unless they are reported on your official high school transcript. The Admission Committee can begin review of your application after receiving all official college transcripts, but may not be able to make a final admission decision until your high school transcript and test scores have been received. All transfer students are required to complete college algebra or a college-level math course before transferring to SMU. If algebra I, geometry and algebra II were taken in high school and graduation was less than three years ago, this requirement is waived. Close × International Transfer Students Description of International Transfer Students here. Close × Performing and Visual Arts All transfer students who intend to major in dance, music, theatre, studio art or film (BFA) must complete an audition or portfolio. Applicants will be considered on both academic standards and on the results of their audition or portfolio. Dance and theatre majors are only admitted for the fall term. Close × Economics Majors To enter SMU as an economics major, transfer students must have 30 or more hours of transfer credit and a minimum all-college cumulative GPA of 2.700. Additionally, students must have a 2.700 GPA on a subset of courses equivalent to SMU’s DISC 1312, (Introduction to Academic Discourse); ECO 1311 (Principles of Microeconomics); ECO 1312 (Principles of Macroeconomics); MATH 1309 (Introduction to Calculus for Business and Social Sciences) or MATH 1337 (Calculus I); and STAT 2301 (Statistics for Modern Business Decisions) or STAT 2331 (Introduction to Statistical Methods). Close × Business Majors Students who plan to major in business can be admitted to SMU as pre-business majors, or they can be admitted directly to the Cox School of Business. To be admitted as a business major, students must be admissible to SMU and must also meet the specific admission requirements for the Cox School of Business. Cox admission requires: 1. A minimum 39 transferable credit hours, and 2. A minimum 3.50 all-college cumulative GPA, and 3. Successful completion of the required subset of courses: Discernment & Discourse 1312 Discernment & Discourse 1313* Economics 1311 Economics 1312 Math 1309/1337 Statistics 2301/2331 (or approved alternative course) Accounting 2301 Close Apply NowVisit UsBack to top Academics Cox School of Business Dedman College of Humanities and Science Dedman School of Law Lyle School of Engineering Meadows Application Process Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Apply Transfer Application Process Application Process Transfer Benefits of an SMU Education Transfer Scholarships Transfer Admission Application Process Transfer Dates and Deadlines Transfer Pathway Guides Transfer Equivalency Tool Meadows Auditions and Portfolios Transfer Forms and Applications International Transfer Students FAQs Congratulations on your admission to SMU! How Credits Transfer Partnership Programs Step 1: Decide which application method is right for you. SMU Application The Common Application ApplyTexas Apply Coalition with SCOIR Transfer Update Form (For students who have previously applied to SMU within the last two years but did not enroll or withdrew before the 12th day of classes.) Step 2: Review and complete the application checklist. Complete your application on time - check the application deadlines Pay $60 nonrefundable application fee* (If you are Pell Eligible or a veteran, you can request an application fee waiver. Contact your Transfer Admission Counselor.) Submit official college transcripts from all previously attended colleges or universities, including dual credit and international coursework a. Applicants who have completed international coursework must also submit a professional evaluation that shows the U.S. equivalence for each educational credential and the credit and grade equivalents for university-level courses. When selecting the type of evaluation, chose a Course-by-Course evaluation. Submit an official high school transcript that includes a graduation date or GED (Optional) Submit official SAT or ACT scores (only if you transfer with less than 24 credit hours). SMU won't require standardized test scores for 2023 undergraduate applicants. We want to ease your mind about applying to SMU. (Optional) Submit extracurricular resume, personal essay, and letters of recommendation as part of your application or to ugadmission@smu.edu (optional but encouraged for scholarship consideration). Review International Transfer Application Process for students transferring from international schools. Review audition and portfolio requirements (students applying for Dance, Music, Theatre, Art, or Film) Step 3: Submit your application materials. Please submit your application online. Supporting documents such as your essay, recommendation letters, or resume can be sent via email to ugadmission@smu.edu. We recommend that transcripts be sent electronically to SMU. If your school does not send electronic transcripts, they can be mailed to the following address: Mailing Address SMU Office of Undergraduate Admission PO Box 750181 Dallas TX 75275 Physical Address (for FedEx, UPS, and DHL shipments): Laura Lee Blanton Building 6185 Airline Road Dallas TX 75205 Please be sure that you indicate your first, middle, and last name as well as your date of birth when you email or mail application materials. If you physically mail your documents, we recommend keeping a copy of all application forms for your records. We look forward to reviewing your application and getting to know you better. If you have questions, don't hesitate to contact the SMU Office of Undergraduate Admission, where any of our transfer admission counselors are ready to help. Phone: 214-768-2058 Fax: 214-768-1083 Office Hours: 8:30 a.m.-5:00 p.m. Central Standard Time Step 4: Track Your Status Track the completion of your application in your personalized Status Page. You will receive an email with your login information within 48-72 hours after you submit your application. * You may pay online through the SMU Online Application, the Common Application, the Coalition for College Application, or the Apply Texas Application. If you are going to pay by check, make the check payable to SMU and mail to the mailing address above. Transfer Dates and Deadlines Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Apply Transfer Transfer Dates and Deadlines Transfer Dates and Deadlines Transfer Benefits of an SMU Education Transfer Scholarships Transfer Admission Application Process Transfer Dates and Deadlines Transfer Pathway Guides Transfer Equivalency Tool Meadows Auditions and Portfolios Transfer Forms and Applications International Transfer Students FAQs Congratulations on your admission to SMU! How Credits Transfer Partnership Programs Application Open Dates All transfer applications for Summer and Fall open on November 1, and our Spring transfer applications open on August 1. Application Recommended Deadlines Fall Admission April 1 (preferred/scholarship deadline) August 1 (final deadline) Spring Admission November 1 Summer Admission June 1 Students pursuing music, dance, theatre, art, or film & media arts (B.F.A. only), please click here for additional information. Application Processing Timeline SMU reviews Transfer Applications on a rolling basis. The application review process for completed Spring Applications will begin in early October, and completed Summer and Fall Applications will start in early March. After the review process has started, we will issue decisions approximately four weeks after all application materials are submitted. You can review the status of your completed application by visiting your personalized status page. You’ll receive an email with login instructions 2-3 days from the date that you apply. Transfer students comprise a large and important component of the total student body and their diverse academic backgrounds enrich the educational experience for all students. These transfer guides are prepared by SMU’s Transfer and Transition Services. They are designed to allow students to easily match transfer coursework with requirements at SMU. Other helpful information such as admission procedures and requirements, academic programs, and course conversions are also included. Careful review of transfer guides should facilitate a seamless transfer to the University and minimize the loss of credit. Transfer counselors in the Office of Admission are available to answer your questions and provide more information. When using the guides, please keep in mind a degree from SMU is typically comprised of a minimum of 120 hours, 60 of which must be completed in residence at SMU. Components of the degree include: Courses in your major Courses required for the Common Curriculum (CC) Elective courses. These electives may also be used to add a second major or minor. Interactive course equivalency guides for many transfer institutions are available on the Transfer and Transition Services’ website. These guides allow students to build a report to see how their courses will transfer to SMU. Specific requirements for transfer admission are found under Transfer Admission Criteria in the Admission section of this catalog. See. Do. Energized by big games, great music and scenic views? While you’re in college and beyond, Dallas has your good time covered with a hot sports scene, myriad concert venues and outdoor trails and lakes galore. Dallas offers everything.There is literally nothing you could long for in D-town. Matthew Merritt ’23 Bishop Arts District Located in the heart of North Oak Cliff, the Bishop Arts District is home to over 60 independent boutiques, restaurants, bars, coffee shops, and art galleries, making it one of Dallas' most unique neighborhoods. Laura Bush Native Texas Park East side of campus A 15-acre nature trail on the George W. Bush Presidential Center grounds where you can explore Texas native plants. Back Katy Trail 0.4 mi. to Katy Trail trailhead One of Dallas' most popular outdoor escapes is near SMU’s campus. Bike, run or walk through Dallas neighborhood and entertainment areas on this 3.5-mile trail. Back Trinity River Audubon Center 14.3 mi. south of campus Immerse yourself in nature south of downtown Dallas. Explore miles of trails and observe birds, butterflies, turtles and other wildlife. Back Trinity Skyline Trail 5.5 mi. from campus Bike or hike this 4.6-mile paved trail to see amazing views of the city. Back White Rock Lake 4.3 mi. from campus The Dallas area is home to several lakes, including iconic White Rock Lake, just east of campus, where you can kayak, get a run in along the shoreline, enjoy a picnic and more. Back MUSTANGS SAY: Dallas offers virtually everything – sport teams, food scene, concert venues and more. Exploring the city has been a highlight of my college experience. Donovan McManus ’24 “Dallas is clearly the star.” 31.8 million fans attended Dallas-area major/minor league and Division I college sporting events over the past five years. Dallas was awarded 15 championship events during the NCAA's most recent round of bidding – more than any other major city. (Sports Business Journal) No. 1 best sports city Sports Business Journal 100+ Hands-on internships and work experiences Sport management students gain real-world work experience at North Texas-based professional sports teams and sport-related agencies and venues. Last year, at least 15 sport management students worked on projects for the Formula 1 French Grand Prix and a European sports marketing agency as part of the SMU-in-France study abroad program. Shopping and dining Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Dallas Experience Menu Search Skip to main content Entertainment Arts and culture Shopping and dining Working in Dallas Community Neighborhoods pause play hide show Hot spots Hit the shops, then grab a bite. Vibrant dining and shopping options make Big D your city for cool finds and great food on every budget. The world dines in Dallas From comforting street food to posh fine dining, Dallas’ diverse food scene represents a multicultural feast that celebrates the cuisines from nearly any spot on the globe. Of course, you can still get our belly-satisfying signature barbecue and tacos with all the trimmings. Let's go eat! Join student foodie Carlie Lara ’24 for a delicious adventure through five of Dallas’ distinctive neighborhoods. “You’re going to have so many places to try when you come here!” Bites on campus! From all-you-care-to-eat dining halls to fast fare to grab-and-go meals, you’ll find a variety of on-campus eats that satisfy most any hungry belly. Chick-fil-A, Panera Bread and Starbucks are among our favorites on the Hilltop, and there’s much more. Eat onsite or get the Grubhub robot to deliver anywhere on campus. Back Bites around campus Five-minute walk from campus: ✓ Olivella’s for delicious pizza or the Original ChopShop for a tasty salad or sandwich. ✓ More delicious eats in nearby Snider Plaza including a deli, juice bar, yogurt as well as German, Italian and Mediterranean cuisines. 10-minute drive or ride DART for chicken wings, tacos, Tex Mex and more, plus many of your favorite fast-dining options. Back When the Parents are Paying: Parents treating you to a special-occasion splurge? Get dressed up and try one of these fine dining experiences: ✓ Al Biernat’s steak house ✓ The French Room (French) ✓ The Mansion Dallas (New American) ✓ Nobu (Japanese) ✓ Trulucks (Seafood) Back Global Cuisines: With a food scene that spans the globe, get ready to diversify your palate. Find global cuisines near campus, or many more while exploring the city: Asian, Asian fusion, Cajun, German, Italian, Japanese, Latin American, Mediterranean, Mexican, Middle Eastern, Tex-Mex, Vietnamese. Back Budget-Friendly Eats: ✓ Affordable quick bites at 7-Eleven convenience store – a five-minute walk from campus or order for delivery. ✓ Favorite fast-dining restaurants a 10-minute drive from campus, or accessible by DART train. Back MUSTANGS SAY: In Dallas, I couldn’t live without the food scene! Every week we try some new restaurant in some new neighborhood. There is truly everything here, and it’s a great place to explore. Blake Gebhardt ’24 Dallas shopping Funky vintage shops, top brands and student-approved resale stores are within a few miles of SMU. Snider Plaza Five-minute walk from campus, on Hillcrest Ave. This convenient family-friendly shopping center covers your basic needs and more with a CVS pharmacy, a Tom Thumb supermarket and myriad restaurants, salons and shops. Back Mockingbird Station 0.4 mi. from campus Trendy shops, spas and movies less than a mile from campus. Back North Park Center 2.8 mi. from campus Dallasʼ preeminent shopping destination with 200+ stores and restaurants. Back The Galleria 9.9 mi. from campus A dining, entertainment and shopping experience that features on-trend brands and an ice-skating rink, a half-hour drive from campus. Back West Village 2.6 mi. from campus Walkable Uptown neighborhood, explore 100-plus shops, restaurants and personal care retailers. Back Preston Center 3.3 mi. from campus From dining spots and retail shops you know to up-and-coming boutiques, within a 10-minute drive from campus. Back Park Cities Plaza Five-minute walk from campus, on Mockingbird Ave. Anchored by the SMU Bookstore, this convenient shopping center is handy for college students. Working in Dallas Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Dallas Experience Menu Search Skip to main content Entertainment Arts and culture Shopping and dining Working in Dallas Community Neighborhoods pause play hide show Classroom to career Top Dallas-area employers seek SMU students for internships and jobs. And our alumni love connecting our students to their industry networks to make career moves. World-ready, industry-prepared With Dallas as their classroom, students have the flexibility to pursue multiple areas of study and get ready for the jobs of the future. MUSTANGS SAY: Guidance from SMU mentors and startup funding from SMU programs – such as Engaged Learning, Big iDeas and the Meadows Exploration Award – helped me achieve my dream of opening my own business. I can support myself while pursuing professional work as an actor. Alysia Giakoumas ’21, Founder/CEO, The Playground Acting Program LLC Internships Build experience before applying for a job. SMU integrates internships and experiential/applied learning opportunities outside of the classroom. Connect with leaders and employers in fields that interest you. Top employers come to SMU After morning football practice, Will Goldberg ’23, who plays safety for the SMU Mustangs, pulls on his steel-toed boots and walks to his internship jobsite located on the SMU campus, where he is an assistant project manager for the Cox School of Business building renovations. He scored the meaningful position after attending an SMU Lyle School of Engineering career fair, where he met Harold MacDowell ’84, CEO of Dallas-based construction firm TDIndustries, Inc., who’s also an SMU alumnus. After one more interview, the mechanical engineering major and math minor was all in. “The three buildings are at different stages, so I’m seeing the whole process,” Goldberg says. “It’s special to work on your own campus and be a part of something that’s going to be there for a very long time.” Will Goldberg ’23 Faculty care about students’ goals Swarangi Potdar ’25 secured a newly created internship with the Dallas Museum of Art, doing curatorial research for the museum’s permanent collection of American art. “It’s an important career builder for students on a museum career track,” says Stephanie Langin-Hooper, associate professor in SMU’s Meadows School of the Arts, who worked with the DMA and SMU’s Hegi Family Career Development Center to create the new position. Potdar, who double majors in finance at SMU Cox School and visual arts at the Meadows School, volunteered with the DMA as a teen ambassador while in high school. After graduation, she plans to pursue a career in art auctions. “Being surrounded with historic artworks is beyond exciting. I look forward to expanding my visual and quantitative skills at analyzing artwork.” Swarangi Potdar ’25 Hands-on experience in a field of interest Olivia Martello ’21 got to detect a fetal heartbeat on her very first day of an internship at White Rock Obstetrics and Gynecology, in Dallas, a fulfilling position she landed thanks to a referral from a classmate and sorority sister at SMU. Martello graduated from SMU’s Simmons School of Education and Human Development with a Bachelor of Science degree in applied physiology and health management, and minored in biological sciences. She continues to prepare for a healthcare career as she finishes up emergency medical technician school and applies to physician assistant programs. “I gained medical knowledge and experienced incredible patient-care interactions.” Olivia Martello ’21 Alumni connections can launch careers Jasmine Smith ’22, ’23 worked on a master’s degree in management and an MBA at SMU Cox School while playing on the women’s basketball team. Thanks to SMU’s Life After Ball program, which helps student-athletes build connections and develop career preparation skills, Smith landed an internship with Dallas-based Hunt Realty Investments, a Life After Ball corporate participant run by SMU alumni Chris Kleinert ’88. Smith recently completed a commercial real estate training program with CRE Analyst. “I appreciated the willingness of SMU alumni to reach out and stay connected with current students.” Jasmine Smith ’22, ’23 Innovation hub Big D was innovating before it was cool. More than 60 years ago, Dallas became the birthplace of the integrated circuit, which would become the microchip. Today, we’re home to startup warriors, cyber defenders, biotech wizards and other innovators who think big and do good. Connecting Entrepreneurs Incubator@SMU – SMU students, faculty and staff who want to launch companies use this business-focused workspace to collaborate with customers, mentors and other entrepreneurs from the Dallas area and beyond. Incubator startups span a variety of industries, including arts, consumer products, consulting, education, technology and more. Bold idea becomes a business Seun Suberu ’23 co-founded the CollegePlus app to help high school students take control of their future. Throughout his SMU student career, Suberu honed new business skills and earned more than $85,000 in funding through multiple SMU competitions designed to jump-start student-led innovation. Variety of industries From health care and energy to finance and technology, the nation’s fourth largest metropolitan area is home to a diverse mix of industries, driving economic growth and employment opportunities. As one of America’s most connected cities, Dallas makes it easy to do business. About 23 Fortune 500 companies think so, too. Our diverse economy is an engine of talent and opportunities, propelling many of our graduates into prominent leadership positions in the area and beyond. Our industry connections include a variety of notable alumni: Matt Alexander ’10, co-founder and CEO, Neighborhood Goods (pictured) David Cush ’82, ’83, former president and CEO, Virgin America David Huntley ’80, Sr. Executive VP & CCO at AT&T Joe Lawrence ’90, EVP and COO, Porsche Thear Sy Suzuki ’96, Americas advisory talent leader, Ernst & Young Amber Venz Box ’08 and Baxter Box ’11, founders, rewardStyle and LTK Movers and shakers The can-do spirit of Dallas is part of SMU's DNA. Here, bold, curious and creative SMU alumni are driven to think big and do good. Do good.® At SMU, community means friends having your back as you push yourself to take risks, and doing your part to shape and improve where you live. New connections, lifelong bonds. Before classes start, you’ll bond with new Mustang classmates while learning about SMU traditions and exploring the city. After move-in, it’s time to get acquainted. Community building starts right away during Stampede, SMU’s orientation event where current students welcome new Mustangs, and help them settle in to their new life on the Hilltop. MUSTANGS SAY: I learned about the service fraternity Alpha Phi Omega from my Stampede guide, and have loved being involved ever since! It’s my favorite group, and the perfect place to give back to the Dallas community and meet new students of all years and majors. Julia Cunningham ’25 Home is where your friends live. Your neighbors could be athletes, dance majors and future engineers – all along the same hallway. First-year students are randomly distributed among the Commons. Find instant community on campus in any of our 11 Residential Commons – where you will live for your first two years at SMU and build lifelong friendships. MUSTANGS SAY: You meet people that you normally wouldn't interact with on campus. It’s a great way to transition to college, especially when you don't know anyone. Anna McDonald ’25 Find your place, shape your experience Shared experiences through campus involvement. Belonging leads to friendships and personal growth. Get involved to help shape where you live and develop leadership skills. With 200-plus student organizations on campus to choose from, you can create your own college experience, find your niche and be part of a support system. MUSTANGS SAY: Serving and leading both a multicultural and a service organization, and being president of my sorority, really enhanced my SMU experience. I definitely recommend getting involved. Dinobi Onyeagocha ’23 Stampeding toward success On day one, Matthew Merritt ’23 started building connections and acquiring experience through involvement with the SMU Association of Black Students, the Upsilon Mu chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity and the SMU chapter of the National Pan-Hellenic Council, and as a student ambassador within the SMU Office of Admission. Off campus, he served as assistant district director for the Texas region of Alpha Phi Alpha, the marketing manager at CollegePlus and was a choral scholar for Wilshire Baptist Church in Dallas. “To be a Mustang is to be a world changer. It’s someone who has the passion, drive and capability to impact their community in a major way, and who has the power to invoke positive change and foster environments for positive growth.” Matthew Merritt ’23 Give back to your college town. World changing starts here when you get involved. Do good. Make a difference. SMU’s Social Change and Intercultural Engagement (SCIE) team connects you with service opportunities on campus and throughout Dallas. Top SCIE service programs: Engage Dallas – Student groups from SMU Residential Commons select sites to serve throughout South and West Dallas. Big Event – In this largest one-day student-run national service project, students across the United States dedicate a day to giving back to their local communities. Mustang Heroes – Students serve through ongoing projects in Dallas. Alternative Breaks – Students perform community service projects during their spring and fall breaks. MUSTANGS SAY: SMU is a pivotal part of Dallas, and students are positively impacting the surrounding area. Abena Marfo ’22 Service with impact. Want to tackle a social problem with a creative, practical solution? Dallas is your classroom. Create a solution that makes a difference. Through SMU programs such as Engaged Learning and undergraduate research opportunities, faculty and staff mentors help you transform your interest or passion into a hands-on learning or service project. You can test ideas with real impact on communities and come away with a real-world experience. Use your voice Tyne Dickson ’22 developed Equity Ahead through SMU’s Engaged Learning Fellowship program. Dickson’s app helps users plan protests and public demonstrations. Undergraduates can do hands-on research Azucena Milan ’20 grew up one mile from SMU’s campus in Dallas’ culturally diverse Vickery Meadow neighborhood, where giant potholes and unlit crosswalks created safety hazards. As an undergraduate, Milan held a key role as part of an SMU research team studying infrastructure inequities on her home turf and learned how environmental engineering impacts daily lives now and in the future. Milan now works as a design engineer at Quiddity Engineering LLC in Dallas. “Maybe one day we can make this happen where all the neighborhoods in the country are treated equitably.” Azucena Milan ’20 Where you go to college matters. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/CampusLife/Dallas/neighborhoods
Neighborhoods Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Dallas Experience Menu Search Skip to main content Entertainment Arts and culture Shopping and dining Working in Dallas Community Neighborhoods pause play hide show Our neighborsare the best With their characteristic vibes and unique twists on art, food, music or shops, Dallas’ distinctive neighborhoods have entertained and inspired generations of SMU students who’ve expanded their worldview and friendships with memorable experiences. Whether you want to hang alone or with your crew, our neighbors have you covered. Lower Greenville 1.8 mi. from campus This vibrant neighborhood is the any-night hang for anyone with an adventurer’s mindset. When you're ready to eat, Lower Greenville has something for everyone from sliders to sushi to frozen treats. Back Deep Ellum 4.9 mi. from campus A historic arts and live music mainstay known for its blues and jazz roots and quirky shops. Back Fair Park 6.0 mi. from campus A festival hub, its crown jewel is the one-and-only State Fair of Texas, arguably the deep-fried food capital of the world every fall with grease-loving, plate-filling and palate-pleasing foods ranging from fried Coke to fried butter and fried Oreos! Back Uptown 3.0 mi. from campus For a variety of budgets, palates and motivations, there are few places that match Dallas' Uptown hot spots. In the mood for shopping, dining, people-watching and a walk after? You'll find that this energetic pedestrian-friendly neighborhood aims to please. Back Bishop Arts 9.4 mi. from campus Spend a Friday night strolling this eclectic neighborhood of galleries, restaurants and shops. When you’re ready for dessert, swing by Emporium Pies for a slice of drunken nut to eat outside where you can savor hand-painted art murals, people watching and live music. Back Downtown Dallas 4.6 mi. from campus History-infused attractions such as the West End Historic District (live music, nightlife, comedy, restaurants) and the Old Red Museum of Dallas County History and Culture (affectionately called "Old Red" as a keeper of Dallas history) hold their own with modern neighbors such as the AT&T Discovery District, a delightful intersection of tech, dining and entertainment. Back Klyde Warren Park 3.8 mi. from campus A distinctive green space built over a freeway, Klyde Warren Park connects Uptown to Downtown. Grab a quick bite from any of the food trucks in the park everyday. And you can catch the free McKinney Avenue Trolley to check out other Dallas attractions along its designated stops. Back Trinity Groves 5.7 mi. from campus Designed by the legendary Santiago Calatrava, the Margaret Hunt Hill Bridge overlooks this unique 15-acre restaurant, retail and entertainment destination. Back Dallas Trails 0.4 mi. to Katy Trail trailhead Linking communities, Dallas’ 160 miles of trails are among “the most beautiful and diverse urban hike and bike trails in the country.”– dallasparks.org Back White Rock Lake 4.2 mi. from campus The Dallas area is home to several lakes, including iconic White Rock Lake, where you can kayak, get a run in along the shoreline, cycle, enjoy a picnic and more. Back Victory Park 4.6 mi. from campus Dirk Nowitzki, in his iconic one-legged fadeaway jump shot, greets fans heading to catch a Mavs game at the American Airlines Center (AAC). The bronze statue reflects the energy and national prominence of the multi-use arena that is home to the Dallas Mavericks basketball team and the Dallas Stars hockey team in Victory Park, where there are plenty of options for dining and nightlife. A few blocks from the AAC, which also hosts big-name concerts, is the Perot Museum of Nature and Science (dinosaur skeletons, interactive exhibits and more). Back Experience Dallas! SMU in Dallas – to us, we’re at the heart of it! Come visit our beautiful campus and explore our city’s distinctive neighborhoods to see firsthand what makes us so special. When you make Dallas your college town, you’ll love it, too! Use this map to start planning your next adventure. MUSTANGS SAY: Dallas is a lively, bustling city with a ton of places to visit and things to do. Monserrat Rodriguez ’25 Where you go to college matters. You owe it to yourself to take advantage of remarkable growth opportunities through SMU and Dallas, an incredible university-city partnership. Visit us so you can see yourself here.
