5 Tips for Applying to an Arts School - Meadows School of the Arts, SMU Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Meadows School of the Arts Areas of Study Admissions About Menu Search Admissions Undergraduate Admission 5 Tips for Applying to an Arts School 5 Tips for Applying to an Arts School Undergraduate Admission Undergraduate Majors and Minors Auditions, Portfolios and the Meadows Application Frequently Asked Questions Take a Virtual Tour 5 Tips for Applying to an Arts School Visit Meadows School of the Arts Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid 5 Tips on How to Double Major 5 tips for applying to an arts school More than talent You may be the best violinist/muralist/filmmaker/dancer/actor in your town. But even if you are a top talent, it can be a challenge to get into the college you want. Your application will be one of many submitted by outstanding high school and transfer students from around the world. To increase your chances of admission, it’s important to keep your academic grades high. Be active in your school or community. Before you send in your application, read college websites and social media to get familiar with their programs and opportunities. Attend info sessions either in person or virtually. When you fill out your application, and you audition or send in your portfolio, let them know what differentiates you from all the other applicants. Be the one who shines. Preparation is key Whether applying for music, dance, theatre, film or studio art, be sure to perform, shoot or create as much as possible while in high school. Music: Performing in summer programs, community productions, master classes, private lessons, for friends and parents, etc. will boost your skills and your confidence. The more you perform, the less nervous you will be at audition time! Research the school’s audition requirements ahead of time and start working on your audition piece well ahead of audition day. Theatre: When choosing audition monologues, help the audition committee get to know you: Choose a character fairly close to you in age from a play about which you passionately care. Although you want to show your range, going too broad can be a trap – the committee may not learn enough about you by seeing you portray an 80-year-old serial killer. Come to the audition ready to play. Stay open to anything thrown at you – welcome the challenges! Dance: Prepare a solo that presents your qualities, technical abilities and expressive range in the best possible light. Get input from your teachers/coaches on the style and content of your solo, and ask them to help you bring it to a high level of performance. Come to the audition thinking of it as a learning opportunity, just as you do when you go to a technique class: Listen carefully to the directions during the audition and don’t be afraid to ask clarifying questions. The most important thing is for the auditioning committee to see the artist in you shining through! Art: Actively create art in your school classes or take classes in your community, and always include time to create art on your own. Explore as many mediums as you can – painting with oil, watercolor, acrylics; drawing with pencil, crayon, charcoal, computer software; try ceramics, sculpture, photography, fine art video and more. Participate in or attend art exhibitions. Visit galleries and museums. Observe the world around you; notice the light, shadows, color, form, people, plants, shapes, everything. Take a close look at artworks you admire and figure out what the artist did to make it connect with you. Film: Watch everything you can: TV, movies, webisodes, social media videos, documentaries, experimental pieces, independent or mainstream, from the U.S. and all over the world. Write, write, write: Nothing happens in filmmaking if there isn’t something written first. Keep coming up with ideas for characters and situations. Look at the news for story ideas; listen to your friends and family; go out an explore the world so you can draw from your own experiences. Portfolios – Art or Film Whether for studio art (any medium) or film and video, start building your portfolio as soon as you can. Curate it – show only your best work, not everything you’ve ever done. Take advantage of college portfolio reviews where you can get one-on-one advice and a clearer idea of what that college is looking for. Many colleges want to see a range of topics and mediums, and some like to see series. They want to see who you are as an artist. Be sure to check out the portfolio requirements before you send in your oeuvre. Be Application Savvy Each performing or visual arts school may require a different repertoire or number of pieces/mediums in a portfolio, and many schools have an intricate set of deadlines for the university admission application and for the audition/portfolio application. Take time to read all of the fine print. Take notes and keep the information about your different schools organized. If the audition requires three pieces and you bring two, the admission committee may not regard your application as highly as they would those who prepared the required three pieces. If something isn’t clear or you want more information, call or email the college’s admission office well in advance of audition days or deadlines. Ask Questions–Lots of Questions Arm yourself with info. How often do students perform, double major, have internships, gallery shows, film fests, opportunities for community engagement? In addition to training in the arts, what kind of entrepreneurship training is available? Are there classes in which you learn how to market yourself, create your own arts venture, build an audience? Is there space for you to put your gear in the school, or do you have to haul everything all over campus? How much access do students have to the faculty? When you zero in on which schools you really want, go visit them. Talk to current students, get a tour, observe a class. Pick up the vibe. Does the school feel right to you? Take Advantage of College Resources If you ask a few weeks in advance, many colleges can arrange for you to observe a class, attend ensemble rehearsals, do free portfolio reviews or see performances by students and faculty. Oftentimes, colleges also bring in high-profile guest speakers and allow the public to attend. Colleges are brimming with activity in your field – check it out, get involved and enjoy a taste of college life! Now is your time to get prepared. Go for it! Want more info? Get additional helpful hints from the admission pros at smu.edu/5tips. Meadows School of the Arts Meadows School of the Arts 6101 Bishop Dallas TX 75205 214-768-2000 Mailing Address: P.O. Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid - Meadows School of the Arts, SMU Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Meadows School of the Arts Areas of Study Admissions About Menu Search Admissions Undergraduate Admission Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Meadows Financial Aid Application Process Dual Admit Financial Package Ranges Meadows FAFSA/CSS Waiver SMU Scholarships and Financial Aid Did you know the cost of college varies from person to person? Depending on your audition or portfolio, academic profile, and family income, you may qualify for academic scholarship, artistic scholarship from Meadows, and/or need-based aid from SMU or the U.S. government. At Meadows School of the Arts, we value talent, dedication, and academic dedication, and strive to ensure that we are creating the best possible financial aid packages for our students. Bottom line: Don't let the price tag scare you. How do students afford Meadows? 8 Million Meadows awards over 8 million dollars of scholarships and grants annually. 3 Out of 4 75% of SMU students receive either scholarship or financial aid from the university. 97% Over 97% of our incoming Dually Admitted students received scholarship or financial aid from the university. Financial aid packages are typically comprised of a combination of need-based funding and scholarships. Possible Components of a Meadows Scholarship/Financial Aid Package SMU ACADEMIC MERIT SCHOLARSHIP MEADOWS ARTISTIC MERIT SCHOLARSHIP First-Year students See SMU Academic Scholarship Programs for more information. Do you have extraordinary leadership qualities and strong academic performance? Be sure to apply for the Hunt Leadership Scholars Program. Transfer Students See Transfer Scholarships for more information. Entering first-year and transfer students majoring in Art, Dance, Film & Media Arts (B.F.A.), Music, or Theatre, and who have been admitted to SMU and to Meadows via audition or portfolio submission are considered for renewable artistic merit scholarships. Scholarship selection is based on audition performance or quality of portfolio, as well as departmental need for the specific discipline/instrument. A separate application is not required for Meadows Artistic Merit scholarship consideration. Award amounts vary by discipline. Minors (Music, Dance, Art) are not considered for artistic scholarships. How to Apply for Financial Aid All Meadows applicants should take the next steps submit financial aid information, or let Meadows know that you don’t intend to apply for financial aid. We need to know either way for scholarship consideration to be complete. Please check out our step-by-step guide on the process of applying for financial aid. If you are Dual Applicant (applying to both SMU and Art, or Dance, Film (BFA), Music, or Theatre), you should check out our Dual Admit financial package ranges to get an idea of how much Meadows Artistic Scholarship and other free money recent Dual Admits were awarded. Meadows Financial Aid Application Process - Meadows School of the Arts, SMU Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Meadows School of the Arts Areas of Study Admissions About Menu Search Undergraduate Admission Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Meadows Financial Aid Application Process Meadows Financial Aid Application Process Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Meadows Financial Aid Application Process Dual Admit Financial Package Ranges Meadows FAFSA/CSS Waiver SMU Scholarships and Financial Aid 1. Apply to SMU and Meadows Apply to SMU and complete any required audition or submit any required portfolio via the Meadows Application. Consult the specific admission checklist for your area for guidelines on when to apply and audition/submit your portfolio. 2. Review Guidelines on when to submit FAFSA and CSS Profile Dual Admit students (Art, Dance, Film and Media Arts [BFA], Music and Theatre) should be sure to submit your FAFSA and CSS profile by January 15. Please note that Meadows artistic scholarships will be determined after all candidates in each Meadows division have been reviewed for admission. Therefore, admitted students should expect final scholarship and financial aid packages between mid-March and early April. Students pursuing degrees in Advertising, Art History, Corporate Communication and Public Affairs, Creative Computing, Fashion Media, Film and Media Arts (BA), Journalism, and Public Relations and Strategic Communication should submit FAFSA and CSS profile by November 1 if applying Early Action or Early Decision I. If applying Regular Decision or Early Decision II, submit the FAFSA and CSS profile by January 15. Not applying for need-based aid? If you do not intend to apply for need-based financial aid, you must submit the Meadows Waiver Form. Trying to decide whether or not to apply for financial aid? The University's Division of Enrollment Services advises that a family income above $350,000 with one child in college is the approximate limit for need-based aid consideration. 3. Submit FAFSA and CSS Profile. Include SMU's school code on your submissions: 6660 (CSS Profile) and 003613 (FAFSA). To help streamline the submission process, use the IRS Data Retrieval Tool to complete the FAFSA. Double check that information on the FAFSA and CSS Profile match. Monitor your email for any additional documents that the SMU Office of Financial Aid may request. FAFSA and CSS Profile forms must be completed every year. FAFSA and CSS Profile are not required for international student applicants. 4. REVIEW the Scholarship/Financial Aid NOTIFICATION TIMELINEs: Academic merit scholarships Students will be notified of any SMU academic merit scholarship they have received with their university admission decision. Artistic merit scholarships Meadows artistic merit scholarships are determined beginning in mid-March, with the bulk of awards being communicated at the end of March/early April. Only students who have been admitted to Meadows and the University with completed FAFSA and CSS Profile forms OR a completed Meadows Waiver Form are considered for artistic scholarships. Notification of artistic scholarships is via email. Meadows Scholar Program Invitations Applicants who have indicated an interest in a Meadows major on their SMU application or submitted a Meadows application and demonstrate strong academic performance in high school are considered for the Meadows Scholar Program. Finalists are notified via email in March. Complete financial aid packages Approximately one week after the Meadows Artistic Merit Scholarship has been finalized, students will be able to log in to my.smu.edu to view their complete SMU Scholarship/Financial Aid Package. Dual Admit Financial Package Ranges - Meadows School of the Arts, SMU Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Undergraduate Admission Student Affairs About SMU News Athletics Events Calendar George W. Bush Presidential Center Prospective Students Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Meadows School of the Arts Areas of Study Admissions About Menu Search Undergraduate Admission Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Dual Admit Financial Package Ranges Dual Admit Financial Package Ranges Undergraduate Scholarships & Financial Aid Meadows Financial Aid Application Process Dual Admit Financial Package Ranges Meadows FAFSA/CSS Waiver SMU Scholarships and Financial Aid Applicants who either audition or submit a portfolio for a major in art, dance, film (BFA), music or theatre are considered for artistic scholarship. To see how artistic scholarship and other grants and scholarships from SMU and Meadows were allocated to dually admitted applicants in each area of study, select the appropriate Meadows major below. Financial Aid Package Ranges 2023 Art Total Art Aid Packages $48,001-$81,000 16% $38,001 - $48,000 10% $20,001 - $38,000 26% $8,001 - $20,000 26% $0 - $8,000 22% Average Artistic Scholarship of Admitted art applicants is $8,580 Average total scholarship and aid package* of admitted art applicants is $26,555 SMU Undergraduate Tuition and Fees 2023-2024 is $64,460 * Does not include loans or work study compensation; the above scholarships + need-based aid packages represent “free money” that does not have to be paid back. Readmission Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Undergraduate Admission Apply Readmission Readmission Apply First Year U.S. Military Veterans International Students Transfer Forms and Applications Readmission Graduate Studies FAQs | Undergraduate Test-Optional Policy Student Resources Returning to the SMU Community If you withdraw from SMU in good academic standing, your file will remain active for one year, and you may register as though in continuous enrollment at the University. If you left on probation, you will return on probation. All holds must be cleared prior to enrollment. Returning students are responsible for meeting all financial aid, housing and advising deadlines. After nonattendance for two regular (fall, spring) terms, students who formerly attended are required to apply for reactivation. Students who were suspended from SMU must apply for reinstatement. If you intend to return to SMU, regardless of whether you are required to apply for reinstatement, you are encouraged to notify the appropriate University departments as soon as possible to ensure timely processing of enrollment, financial aid, housing and other documents. Transcripts If you attended any college or university after leaving SMU, you must forward official transcripts from each college or university attended since your last enrollment at SMU. If five years or more have elapsed since your last term of enrollment at SMU, you must also forward official transcripts from each college or university attended prior to SMU to the Division of Enrollment Services. Transfer courses from another institution Once you have matriculated at SMU, you may transfer up to 30 hours to SMU from an accredited, four year institution. Any course to be transferred must have the prior approval of the chair of the department and dean of the school at SMU that normally offers the course, the adviser and the student's dean. You must obtain these approvals before taking any such courses. Petitions to attend another college or university during the summer must be completed and approved in advance to ensure that proper credit is awarded. Petition forms are available in the Undergraduate Offices. You are responsible for making sure that a transcript of all transfer work attempted is sent to the University registrar immediately following completion of the work. PLEASE NOTE: ALL post-matriculation transfer work must be completed at accredited, four-year institution. It is imperative that you petition ALL post-matriculation transfer courses PRIOR to enrollment in courses using the Undergraduate Petition for Advance Approval of Transfer Credit. Student can also complete/submit a paper version of this form here. Students who fail to get prior approval for transfer work have no assurances that they will receive credit for their courses. Academic forgiveness Any academic work taken 10 or more years prior to the term of admission or reinstatement may be forgiven, and excluded from your GPA calculation or hours earned to determine your eligibility for admission, academic probation, suspension, honors and graduation. Name change If your name has changed since your last enrollment at SMU, or if your name changes from the name submitted on your application for admission, you must provide your Social Security card or the form issued by the U.S. Social Security Administration. Without these documents, you cannot be enrolled under your new name. All grade reports, transcripts, and diplomas are issued only under your legal name as recorded by the University registrar. These programs help students to pursue their passions and make significant contributions in both academia and industry. Kim Herman Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Kim Herman Kim Herman Director of Transfer Admission 214-768-2058 kaherman@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2019 Favorite thing about SMU: Our transfer students! They typically come to SMU with a strong sense of what they want to study and learn from our amazing faculty. They also come from diverse backgrounds and bring incredible experiences to campus, truly enriching student life here at SMU! Favorite place on campus: Dallas Hall. In the fall of 1915, when SMU’s first opened, Dallas Hall was the center of the university, housing a bookstore, soda fountain, grill, and a barber shop, in addition to offices, classrooms, and the library. Now that campus has expanded, it is now home to the famous university seal, classrooms, and offices. And on a clear day you can see all of Dallas from the steps of the building!Favorite place in Dallas: I love the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Gardens! It is a beautiful place to visit any time of year!What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: If you happen to visit in October I would highly recommend that you visit the State Fair of Texas, conveniently located in Fair Park just a short drive from campus. Outside of October, you can get an amazing appreciation of the Dallas Skyline by walking the Margaret Hunt Hill Bridge and after your walk, you can visit Trinity Groves our Restaurant Concept Incubator. #RuralCommunity Admission Staff Claire Aherns Dante Branch Sydney Castle Jeremy Brown Anna Lee Buehn Joe Davis Ayah Krisht Joe Francisco Brenda Del Rio Rick Diaz Kim Herman Elena D. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/Claire-Aherns
Claire Aherns Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Claire Aherns Claire Aherns Assistant Director of Admission Events 214-768-2058 ahrensc@smu.edu Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2022 Favorite thing about SMU: The beautiful campus! SMU is its own little oasis in the heart of Dallas, Texas. Nothing I love more than taking time in between meetings to take a walk around campus! You will always see friendly faces, and nothing beats the views when the leaves begin to change in the fall! Favorite place on campus: My favorite place on campus has to be Hughes-Trigg! I love getting to see students and faculty grabbing a bite to eat in between classes. There is always something going on and it’s the best place to meet up with friends and colleagues on campus! Don’t forget to grab an Icee from The Market! Favorite place in Dallas: When I am not at work you can find me at Griggs Park in Uptown! It is one of my favorite views of downtown Dallas. I also love all the puppies there! Favorite restaurant near campus: Dallas has some really wonderful restaurants, so it’s hard to pick! My top three would have to be Oishii, Honor Bar, and E Bar Tex-Mex! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: You have to check out the Knox Street area – so many shops and restaurants in the area. Make sure to stop by Knox Bistro or RH Rooftop! URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/Dante-Branch
Dante Branch Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Dante Branch Dante Branch Assistant Director of Admission214-768-2058danteb@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I joined the Office of Admission: 2023 Favorite thing about SMU: There is nothing I love more than the campus! Imagine spending the next few years of your life in the heart of the best city in the world (Dallas, Texas); I love how the students have access to art, culture, commerce and innovation at their fingertips. I can only imagine discovering new knowledge not only for the sake of your GPA, but also to improve your intellectual skills and create a meaningful impact on society. I am also impressed by the fact that SMU attracts a diverse student body from all over the United States as well as from abroad. SMU students are trailblazers in their own right. Undergraduates at SMU are driven to pursue their passions and dreams by taking the path less traveled. Above all, SMU students are empowered to maximize their potential. Favorite place on campus: A Saturday night football game at Gerald J. Ford Stadium is one of my favorite things to do in Dallas, as I am a huge football fan. The next time you are in town on a Saturday night, do yourself a favor and attend a game at Ford Stadium. Favorite place in Dallas: A great place to stop and relax as you make your way through downtown Dallas is Klyde Warren Park. The beautiful public park is a place of respite tucked in the middle of the downtown streets and high-rise buildings. On any given day, you can enjoy food trucks, outdoor dining, green space, public art and a casual social scene. Favorite restaurant near campus: Café 43. Lunch at this restaurant is of the highest quality. Unfortunately, they do not serve dinner. It is my favorite. It is ideal for business lunches. The service is excellent, the food is delicious and the atmosphere is amazing. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: There are a number of places that families can visit during their stay in Dallas, including the Dallas World Aquarium, the Perot Museum of Nature and Science and the Dallas Zoo. One of the most popular family-friendly attractions in Dallas is the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Garden, which is known for its unique seasonal displays. If you are interested in history, you might also want to visit the Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza, Pioneer Plaza, the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum or Deep Ellum, one of the city’s first commercial districts that is now a hub for art, dining and live entertainment and is filled with free activities. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/Sydney-Castle
Sydney Castle Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Sydney Castle Sydney Castle Admission Counselor 214-768-2058 sydneycastle@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2020 (as an ambassador) 2023 (as a counselor) Favorite thing about SMU: One of the most distinctive and remarkable aspects of SMU that differentiates us from other universities is the structure of our student organizations. A prominent example is the Student Foundation, which stands as the largest programming organization on our campus, responsible for coordinating significant events like Homecoming and Family Weekend. Unlike most other colleges and universities that rely on full-time staff to organize such events, SMU empowers its students by granting them the opportunity and autonomy to plan our most cherished traditions. This hands-on, real-life experience is exceptionally rare and provides students with invaluable learning opportunities; and at SMU, there is an abundance of such enriching experiences readily available. The organizations I was involved in as a student not only played a pivotal role in shaping me as an individual but also gave me a family. Favorite place on campus: When I first came to SMU, I had the opportunity to interview for the Hunt Scholarship, which took place in Harold Clark Simmons Hall. Following the interview, I came across the area near the back entrance of Fondren Library, where there are benches and pods of flowers. I sat on one of the benches to call my mom and tell her all about the interview. After about an hour, it was clear to both of us that I had fallen in love with SMU and I HAD to spend the next four years of my life here. Every time I pass this spot, I always think back to the moment I knew this was going to be my home. Favorite place in Dallas: Choosing just one favorite is impossible, but two of my favorite places are Barley House and Louie Louie’s Piano Bar. Barley House, conveniently located across the street from school, became our weekend haven, where my friends and I spent hours catching up, cheering for sports games, and supporting our talented musician friends who created a band and sometimes performed there. On the other hand, Louie Louie’s is located in Deep Ellum and the audience requests songs to sing along to until the early hours of the morning. These unforgettable moments really shaped my experience in Dallas. Favorite restaurant near campus: There are so many new restaurants that have popped up near campus since I first came to SMU that I absolutely love, like DL Mack’s and Ramble Room. However, when it comes to my ultimate favorite, I have to go with Banditos. In college, Banditos became the go-to place for my friends and me, no matter the occasion or mood. If we were happy, we would go there to celebrate, and we would also go if we needed a “pick me up” because the vibes simply cannot be beat! Banditos has a very special place in my heart. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: Highland Park Village is an absolute must-see, particularly at night when the lights illuminate the trees. There are fabulous restaurants that are worth going to, such as Honor Bar, Mi Cocina, Fachini and Lounge 31. While you’re exploring the area, I highly recommend taking a stroll along the Katy Trail, immersing yourself in the charming atmosphere of the Knox/Henderson area, and driving around the neighborhoods that surround campus. As an SMU student, you are truly fortunate to be situated in such a beautiful and safe residential environment. Students definitely take advantage of having an abundance of remarkable restaurants, charming cafes and unique shops at your fingertips, making your college experience all the more enriching and enjoyable. Jeremy Brown Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Jeremy Brown Jeremy Brown Associate Director of Admission/Director for International Admission +1-214-768-2058 jeremyb@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2015 Favorite thing about SMU: It’s hard to pick just one—among my favorite things about SMU are: the strong academic programs and research opportunities for students; our diverse, welcoming campus community; the beautiful buildings and grounds (it’s no wonder our campus was named the 2nd most beautiful campus in the U.S.!); the close proximity to the amazing city of Dallas, and last, but not least; the contagious school spirit that goes beyond our athletic programs, but is felt throughout the entire University. Pony up! Favorite place on campus: The Dedman Center for Lifetime Sports. Not because I’m using the state-of-the-art workout facilities or beautiful pools, but because it houses the brand-new Starbucks! Favorite place in Dallas: My favorite place in Dallas is the Bishop Arts neighborhood. It is incredibly diverse, multicultural and funky. On one corner, I can get amazing pupusas from a small El Salvadorian restaurant and on the next corner eat at one of the many delicious, incredibly creative restaurants where all the Dallas foodies go! Favorite restaurant near campus: So many great options-- but I'll go with the Dallas-based, Velvet Taco! They take traditional street tacos and add their own creative global spin. From the traditional Mexican flavors, to Southern, to Indian, and beyond. Definitely don't miss out on their delicious sides. My favorites are their Elote Corn and their loaded Crisp Tots with Local Egg-- it's all so delicious! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: Check out the Arts District. There you’ll find the Dallas Museum of Art (which is awesome and, best of all, free!), the Nasher Sculpture Center (incredibly unique collection of contemporary and modern sculptures), and Klyde Warren Park (a very cool, large park which sits above one of Dallas’ busiest highways and has delicious food trucks!). Anna Lee Buehn Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Anna Lee Buehn Anna Lee Buehn Assistant Director of Admission 214-768-8464 alee@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2022 Favorite thing about SMU: I love the campus! From the moment I first stepped onto the Boulevard, I knew SMU was the place for me. This place is beautiful, and I love being here when all the students are outside enjoying it. Each undergraduate college has its own personality and vibe. I love walking into Meadows to catch a glimpse of dress rehearsal performances. Dedman College is a classic on campus, but don’t get caught stepping on the seal in Dallas Hall! Rumor has it, you won’t graduate in 4 years. Cox conversations are my favorites to observe. Lyle’s innovation and technology on display inspire me to think about the future; and with education being my favorite subject, it’s hard for me not to find a kindred spirit at Simmons. It’s so much fun being on campus and experiencing it all over again. Favorite place on campus: That’s a tough one, but I’d have to say the Meadows School of the Arts. The college just finished a 2.5 year renovation and the space is spectacular! The talent housed in Meadows is off the charts! I love walking the halls and hearing vocal and instrumental warmups. The art on display is incredible! And the students…I don’t think there are a cooler group of people on campus! Favorite place in Dallas: My family and I love birds and wildlife. The John Bunker Sands Wetland Center is a short drive just outside of the city but the perfect escape from the hustle and bustle. It’s less than 30 minutes from campus. Check it out! Favorite restaurant near campus: I LOVE so many; it’s hard to choose! When in Texas, I believe it’s criminal not to experience Tex Mex. Rusty Taco has the best breakfast tacos in town! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: Dallas has great shopping, restaurants, and art! I’d say spend the morning at the Nasher Sculpture Gardens, enjoy lunch at the Klyde Warren Park food trucks, and head over to Highland Park Village for some afternoon shopping. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/JoeDavis
Joe Davis Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Joe Davis Joe Davis Associate Dean of Admission 214-768-2058 josephd@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2006 Favorite thing about SMU: My favorite thing about SMU is the unique relationship we have with the city of Dallas. Dallas doesn’t exist because of SMU, and SMU doesn’t exist because of Dallas. We have a great symbiotic relationship that opens students up to all the benefits of being in a big city, but you’re not going to class right in the middle of downtown. As an SMU student, you get the benefits of living on a residential campus in residential area, but the hustle and bustle of downtown is only minutes away. Between job and internship opportunities, entertainment venues, and opportunities to serve the community, this relationship allows our students to experience the best of both worlds in terms of campus location. Favorite place on campus: Moody Coliseum, without a doubt. When Moody was renovated in 2014, it reopened to a packed house of fans and a landslide Mustang victory of the U-Conn Huskies. I am a huge basketball fan, and the level of detail involved in the interior of Moody is awesome. It’s a great place to watch a basketball game: there’s not a bad seat in the house, it gets really loud really quickly, and the energy during games is unmatched. I try not to miss a single game! Favorite place in Dallas: The AT&T Performing Arts Center is among my favorite places in Dallas. Between the national tours that come to the Winspear Opera House to Meadows at the Meyerson (where our talented SMU Meadows student perform in the Meyerson Symphony Center), there are so many incredible performances that take place in this top-notch collection of performing arts venues. You’ll find yourself on the north end of the Dallas arts district and right in the midst of some incredible restaurant options, too. Favorite restaurant near campus: Definitely Campisi’s on Mockingbird. Campisi’s is a Dallas staple that’s been around since 1946. They have an awesome menu of Italian food, but their pizza is my favorite. Instead of traditional mozzarella, Campisi’s uses smoked provolone as their cheese of choice on their pizzas. You will 100% smell like pizza when you leave, but it’s absolutely worth it. (When in doubt, go for the Italian sausage and salami for your pizza toppings!) What I recommend you do during your stay in Dallas: In one word, explore! One of the best things about Dallas is that there are a ton of different neighborhoods with a ton of different things to do and see. I would encourage you to check out the Bishop Arts District, Deep Ellum, Knox/Henderson, White Rock Lake… do it all! There’s truly something for everyone in Dallas, whether you’re into music, shopping, local venues, or national names. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/Ayah-Krisht
Ayah Krisht Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Ayah Krisht Ayah Krisht Admission Counselor 214-768-6739 akrisht@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I joined Office of Admission: 2023 Favorite thing about SMU: My favorite thing about SMU is the way it makes every student feel like they belong. When I first moved onto campus my freshman year, I didn’t know anyone. This excited me as I attended college out of state specifically for this experience, but when my parents left, reality definitely started to settle in. However, I didn’t have time to even start to get nervous before my residential commons hosted the largest water balloon fight I had ever been a part of. By the end of my first day, I had an entire group of budding friendships with people I still talk to today, four years later. Home is where the Hilltop is. Favorite place on campus: This is one of the hardest questions to answer, but I think I have to go with the Dallas Hall Lawn. When I was searching for colleges as a high school senior and narrowing down my options, one thing that became really important to me was my ability to picture myself walking around and living my daily life on campus. SMU topped every option on my list, and I truly think that was because of our Dallas Hall Lawn. Every day, without fail, students are studying together, walking their dogs, going on picnics, boulevarding, etc. In my mind, it’s SMU’s signature! Favorite place in Dallas: There is ALWAYS something to do in the Dallas Arts District. I’m a big art-lover, so I may be a little bit biased, but any time I bring a friend there, they beg me to take them back!! Lots of food and entertainment options, and the best part is…. it only takes 15 minutes to get there! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: I have to use one of these questions to brag about the food scene in Dallas. Some of my favorite restaurants that are SMU student classics are: Penne Pomodoro in Snider Plaza, Mi Cocina in Highland Park Village, Il Bracco at the Preston Center, and HG Supply Co. on Greenville. Joe Francisco Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Joe Francisco Joe Francisco Regional Director of Admission 713-836-0931 jfrancisco@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2023 Favorite thing about SMU: The diversity of the student body and the students themselves, as well as the beautiful campus and sense of community. Everyone has a story and their own experience creating a unique and positive culture when they meet at SMU. Students can get involved from Day One, including more than 200 clubs and organizations to be a part of. Strong traditions and history, as well as the tremendous support of faculty, staff and our great alumni network help make SMU a great place to be. Also, the strong connection that SMU has with the city of Dallas – located just a few short miles from downtown, students have access to all of the amenities of a large city, including the arts, entertainment, restaurants, music, sports, great restaurants, and shopping. SMU truly is a hidden gem within the big city! Favorite place on campus: It’s difficult to pick just one favorite place because each building has its own personality and uniqueness, all while sharing the tradition and values of SMU. The architecture and landscape on campus is just beautiful, and if you’re an art-lover like myself, be sure to check out the Meadows Museum of Art, housing one of the largest collections of Spanish art outside of Spain. Favorite place in Dallas: My favorite place is seeing something new and different! Dallas offers so much and there’s always something to do, whether it’s the museums, beautiful parks, including running and biking trails and lakes (yes, there are great parks in and around the big city!), checking out a concert, attending a professional sports game (NBA-Mavs, WNBA-Wings, NHL-Stars, MLB-Rangers, NFL-Cowboys), cheering on the Mustangs on our campus, or visiting the State Fair of Texas in the Fall – there is so much on my list that I’m excited to explore every time I visit Dallas and am on campus! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: Go check out the museums in and around the city, like the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum (on campus!), the Perot Museum of Nature and Science and The Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza in downtown Dallas. The city offers the nation’s largest urban arts district downtown! Also, you’ll find great restaurants of all types, no matter what you’re craving. With so many amazing food options in the area – just ask anyone when you’re on campus and you’ll probably get a different delicious recommendation! Brenda Del Rio Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Brenda Del Rio Brenda Del Rio Admission Counselor214-768-2058bdelrio@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined Office of Admission: 2021 Favorite thing about SMU: The opportunities! Whether you are a student looking for an education or a staff member for SMU, the opportunities to learn, grow, and experience new things is never ending. Everyone here wants to see each other succeed, and that kind of support is simply unmatched. Favorite place on campus: The Hughes-Trigg Student Center is definitely one of my favorite places to hang out in. Since it has been renovated, it has allowed our students to thoroughly enjoy some of the great things SMU has to offer, such as innovative study/meeting spaces and fantastic food options like Panera. I love seeing the students hard at work, hanging out with their friends, or making conversation with some of our Dining Services staff members. If there is any place that can best capture SMU’s vibe, it is the Hughes-Trigg Student Center! Favorite place in Dallas: As someone who was born and raised in Dallas, this is hard! But if I *have* to choose a place, it would probably be Fair Park, because it is home to the famous State Fair of Texas and Big Tex himself! Every year, Dallas is honored to host the Texas State Fair which has an incredible amount of activities and amusement rides- good luck getting to them all! By far the best thing about the Texas State Fair is the good people and GREAT food. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: There are so many fun and unique things to do in Dallas, such as visiting Deep Ellum or the Perot Museum in the Arts District. What I definitely recommend is visiting the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Gardens. Whether you want to snap a pic for social media or simply immerse yourself into all of the beauty nature has to offer, the Dallas Arboretum is absolutely stunning and a people-pleaser for all ages. Rick Diaz Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Rick Diaz Rick Diaz Regional Director of Undergraduate Admission Southern California562-439-9601rdiaz@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I joined the Office of Admission: 1991 Favorite thing about SMU: The students. Yes I am biased in that my niece is a junior majoring in Civil Engineering. But, she is just one of the hundreds of students from southern California that have embraced the spirit of SMU and have made SMU such a great place. SMU students are awesome and make SMU truly unique among universities world-wide. Favorite place on campus: The Meadows Museum of Art allows me to step through the portals of time and place. Walking through the museum, you get a sense of history and culture. I could easily spend hours surrounded by the masterpieces housed there. Favorite place in Dallas: The Sixth Floor Museum at Dealey Plaza chronicles the assassination and legacy of President John F. Kennedy. Taking the tour is a moving experience and you will forever be affected by this historic place. Favorite restaurant near campus: Gloria’s on Greenville Avenue is not to be missed. Once you step inside, the smells transport you to place of pure gastronomic delight. This is not your typical Latin American eatery. The food is authentic and savory. I highly recommend the Sopa de Siete Mares. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: If you are reading this, you are most likely from southern California. Go to the NorthPark Mall and listen to the conversations around you. While some of the words may be different with a “y’all” or two thrown in, the topics are no different than the ones you would hear at your local mall. Feel comfortable in the similarities and embrace the differences. And if you start to feel like it is too far from southern California – stop by the nearest In-N-Out for a double-double and a chocolate shake. By the way, there are 16 In-N-Out Burgers in the Dallas Metroplex area and one a mile from campus. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Kim Herman Kim Herman Director of Transfer Admission 214-768-2058 kaherman@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2019 Favorite thing about SMU: Our transfer students! They typically come to SMU with a strong sense of what they want to study and learn from our amazing faculty. They also come from diverse backgrounds and bring incredible experiences to campus, truly enriching student life here at SMU! Favorite place on campus: Dallas Hall. In the fall of 1915, when SMU’s first opened, Dallas Hall was the center of the university, housing a bookstore, soda fountain, grill, and a barber shop, in addition to offices, classrooms, and the library. Now that campus has expanded, it is now home to the famous university seal, classrooms, and offices. And on a clear day you can see all of Dallas from the steps of the building!Favorite place in Dallas: I love the Dallas Arboretum and Botanical Gardens! It is a beautiful place to visit any time of year!What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: If you happen to visit in October I would highly recommend that you visit the State Fair of Texas, conveniently located in Fair Park just a short drive from campus. Outside of October, you can get an amazing appreciation of the Dallas Skyline by walking the Margaret Hunt Hill Bridge and after your walk, you can visit Trinity Groves our Restaurant Concept Incubator. #RuralCommunity Admission Staff Claire Aherns Dante Branch Sydney Castle Jeremy Brown Anna Lee Buehn Joe Davis Ayah Krisht Joe Francisco Brenda Del Rio Rick Diaz Kim Herman Elena D. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/Jermaine-Merritt
Jermaine Merritt Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Jermaine Merritt Jermaine Merritt Assistant Director of Transfer Admission 214-768-2058 jermainem@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2023 Favorite thing about SMU: My favorite thing about SMU is the school spirit and pride. Everyone is truly happy and proud to be a part of SMU; it shows daily whether it’s inside the classroom, out and about on campus, or within the nearby businesses and neighborhoods. In a city that’s as large as Dallas, it truly makes you feel at home and have a sense of community on the Hilltop. Favorite place on campus: My favorite place on campus would have to be the Hughes-Trigg Student Center. This is a hub of student life on campus. From housing student organizations and offices, meeting rooms for organizations to meet or students to study, and housing my favorite place – Chick-fil-A, it’s truly buzzing with activity always. Favorite place in Dallas: I would have to say my favorite place in Dallas is the Lower Greenville district. Full of restaurants, local shops, bakeries and more, Lower Greenville is a great way to escape the true hustle and bustle of Dallas and move at a slower place with a great atmosphere. Favorite restaurant near campus: I would have to say my favorite restaurant near campus is Rusty Taco. Only three minutes away from campus, Rusty Taco is a staple in the Dallas area. Offering a variety of delicious taco options, they have something for everyone. I would recommend going for one of the breakfast tacos; a win every time! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: During your stay in Dallas, I would recommend checking out Klyde Warren Park. Located in downtown Dallas, Klyde Warren Park is an outdoor park that goes over one of our Dallas freeways! It’s a great place to hang out outside and have a picnic or enjoy food from one of the various food trucks, and only a three-minute walk from the Dallas Museum of Art. Dave Morrin Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Dave Morrin Dave Morrin Regional Director of Undergraduate Admission Florida, Georgia, Alabama and Puerto Rico 904-737-2422 dmorrin@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2022 Favorite thing about SMU: The people. SMU is special, and I hope you visit campus to feel it! I came here from a large public university in Florida, where close community felt unattainable. You’re never a number at SMU, and you aren’t lost in crowds. Professors care about you, including enriching Faculty-in-Residence who live in Residential Commons. I’m the first person in my family to go to college, so I’m especially proud of SMU’s First-Generation Initiative. Favorite place on campus: I love our abundant fountains, plus the tanning pool outside of the Dedman Center for Lifetime Sports—where you’ll find a climbing wall, pool, gyms, indoor track, sports courts and more. But my favorite spot is the Wave sculpture outside the phenomenal Meadows Museum of Art. It’s a moving, undulating, kinetic sculpture above a reflecting pool. An engineering wonder! Favorite place in Dallas: Pelican Point at White Rock Lake! This gorgeous spot is perfect for when you’re homesick for Georgia’s Chattahoochee or Lake Lanier, or if you’re a paddleboarding Floridian like me who loves beautiful sunsets over calm water. Watch the sailboats sharing waves with pelicans, swans, and ducks. Head to the lake to study, run, bike, and find serenity in quiet nature. Favorite restaurant near campus: Desperados is a fantastic Tex-Mex restaurant close to campus. It’s an authentic family-run restaurant rooted in showcasing the culinary diversity of Mexico, while also serving untraditional twists and modern favorites like their famous Desperados Tacos. To satisfy your sweet tooth, stop by Chocolate Secrets—a dessert gem that offers handmade gourmet chocolates and lively open mic nights. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: Go downtown to see the Giant Eye—the weirdest but coolest eyeball sculpture you’ve ever seen. Keep walking down Elm Street to the Grassy Knoll and Dealey Plaza, the historic site of JFK's assassination. The depth and diversity of Dallas will be on full display! Scan the city skyline and picture your future at SMU—you want to choose a city and university that feels like home. #FirstGen Admission Staff Claire Aherns Dante Branch Sydney Castle Jeremy Brown Anna Lee Buehn Joe Davis Ayah Krisht Joe Francisco Brenda Del Rio Rick Diaz Kim Herman Elena D. Jacqueline Ortiz Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Jacqueline Ortiz Jacqueline Ortiz Admission Counselor214-768-2058jacquelineo@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I Joined the Office of Admission: 2021 Favorite thing about SMU: I love how it can feel like a small school and a large school at the same time. You have that close-knit community feeling that a smaller campus can bring, while also benefiting from the sports, extra-curriculars, and school spirit of a larger school. Favorite place on campus: The Fondren Library would have to be my favorite. There are so many different kinds of spaces that can fit whatever kind of workspace you may need. Not to mention, there is a Starbucks inside so you can easily grab that caffeine boost you may need. Favorite place in Dallas: As a Dallas native, I love the Vickery Meadow area (just northeast of campus) for a nice and simple Saturday afternoon. There’s an Alamo Drafthouse movie theater, a Topgolf location, the Park Lane shopping center, and the Half-Price Books flagship location. In addition to that, there are many great local restaurants that are not to be missed. I would recommend Keller’s Hamburgers for that drive-in experience or Mariano’s Hacienda Ranch for delicious Mexican food. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: Definitely make time to go on the M-Line Trolley. It travels through parts of downtown and a lot of Uptown, and it’s just a neat way to get to know the city. The best part – it’s free! #Bilingual #FirstGen Admission Staff Claire Aherns Dante Branch Sydney Castle Jeremy Brown Anna Lee Buehn Joe Davis Ayah Krisht Joe Francisco Brenda Del Rio Rick Diaz Kim Herman Elena D. You get an amazing city feel and benefits without the overwhelming feeling of being in the city. Being in Dallas provides many opportunities for students. Favorite Place on Campus: While there are so many places to love at SMU, my favorite places are the Dedman Center for Lifetime Sports and the Historic Main Quad! The architecture and landscape on campus are so beautiful and a great way to run into students while enjoying The Texas sun! Favorite Place in Dallas: My favorite place in Dallas is American Airlines center, it is great from anything from seeing your favorite artist to watching the Mavs! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: I recommend trying some amazing Tex Mex and Barbecue restaurants and visiting our downtown! Abbi Pfister-Soria Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Abbi Pfister-Soria Abbi Pfister-Soria Director of Recruitment 214-768-2058 apfister@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Year I joined the Office of Admission: 2007 Favorite thing about SMU: The school spirit and traditions for a university that has been around for only 100 years! There is really a great sense that it’s a family of current student, alums, faculty and staff. I could be walking through any airport in the country and I will always get a “Go Mustangs!” or alums will show their pony pride with their “Pony Up” hand signal. Favorite place on campus: As a supporter of the arts, I love spending time in the Meadows Museum of Art. An oasis of Spanish Culture, it’s amazing that our students have these types of resources at their fingertips. If you are planning on visiting campus and want to check it out, keep in mind they are closed on Mondays. Favorite place in Dallas: Sitting behind the goal on the South Plaza of the American Airlines Center cheering on the Dallas Stars, the NHL franchise. Plus on occasion SMU students and staff get great discounts on tickets. Favorite restaurant near campus: Half-Shells in Snider Plaza. Coming from the East Coast I love great seafood and Half-Shells is a great place to get my fix. What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: If you have an extra half day head out to the Dallas Arboretum, this is a great oasis just 3 miles away from campus and overlooks White Rock Lake. If you catch it at the right time you might see our women’s crew team practicing! URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/ConnectWithUs/Counselors/Staff/Lissette-Zavala
Lissette Zavala Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Find your admission counselor Admission Staff Lissette Zavala Lissette Zavala Transfer Admission Counselor214-768-8724lzavala@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 Favorite Thing about SMU: My favorite thing about SMU is the feeling of being in a small town when in reality, you are in the center of the big city of Dallas. Being on campus, you get the sense of how close of a community there is here. Everyone is welcoming and always willing to help. Favorite place on campus: My favorite place on campus has to be Dallas Hall and especially the views outside of the front doors. Dallas Hall is majestic on the inside and takes you back in time because of the historical significance of this building. I imagine the first students of SMU walking to their classes, and it is such a neat feeling. Also, when standing outside the front doors, you get the best view of the campus and the city of Dallas. Favorite place in Dallas: My favorite place in Dallas is White Rock Lake. It is a great place to be outdoors and enjoy some nature while living in the rush of the city. I like to go kayaking and take long walks there to disconnect and get some nice exercise for the week. Favorite restaurant near campus: My favorite restaurant near campus is Velvet taco! I like that they have fusion tacos that allow you to try something new. Of course, you have to try the tater tots too! What I recommend during your stay in Dallas: As a Dallas native, there is so much I can recommend! Dallas has some unique neighborhoods like Deep Ellum and Bishop Arts to explore. Also, there are so many great places to eat. Check out the Trinity Groves area for a diverse lineup of restaurants. I am also a huge Dallas sports fan; if you have the time, go to a Mavs game or Texas Rangers game. URL: https://smu.edu/Admission/Apply/Frequently-Asked-Questions-TestOptional
FAQs | Undergraduate Test-Optional Policy Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Undergraduate Admission Apply FAQs | Undergraduate Test-Optional Policy FAQs | Undergraduate Test-Optional Policy Apply First Year U.S. Military Veterans International Students Transfer Forms and Applications Readmission Graduate Studies FAQs | Undergraduate Test-Optional Policy Student Resources Submitting Test Scores How long is the test-optional policy in place? SMU is currently fully test-optional. How do I know if I should submit my test scores or not? Admission and scholarship decisions are based on many factors including information from applicants’ high school transcript, personal essay, letters of recommendation, and record of personal achievements in addition to SAT or ACT scores. Under this policy, applicants who choose not to submit ACT or SAT scores will be evaluated on the other factors. Do you superscore standardized test scores? For those who choose to submit scores, SAT and ACT scores are superscored. Self-reported test scores are also accepted. If I choose to self-report test scores, will I be able to report one specific section of the SAT or ACT? For self-reported scores, provide scores for each section of the exam. Partial scores will not be considered. If I submit test scores will I be looked at more favorably than those who do not? No preference is given to applicants who submit or do not submit test scores. Grade/GPA-Related Questions If my grades were impacted by COVID-19, what should I do? All application materials are looked at in context. Many students have seen their academic record impacted by COVID-19, and items will be viewed through that lens. What if my school uses Pass/Fail grades during the Spring 2020 semester? Pass/Fail grades or any other official grading system submitted by your school will be considered in our admission review. If I do not submit test scores, will you put more weight on my GPA? Without test scores, all other elements of your application become more important, including grades, résumé, essays and recommendation letters. Extracurricular Activities My extracurricular activities have been put on hold because of COVID-19, how will they be evaluated during the admission process since many were cancelled? It is understood that most extracurricular activities will be affected in the foreseeable future, and the potential gap in activities will not affect admission to SMU. Cox School of Business If I do not submit test scores, will I be considered for admission to the Cox School of Business? Yes, the Cox School of Business will review all students who list business as an academic interest/major on their application. Scholarship Consideration If I choose not to submit my test scores, will it impact my ability/chances of receiving a merit award? No, academic merit scholarships are awarded to over half of the students in its entering class each fall. They range in value from $20,000 to $30,000 per year and more. These scholarships do not require a separate application and will also follow a test-optional process. If I take the SAT or ACT after I am admitted, can I submit those scores later for scholarship consideration? Yes, additional information for scholarship consideration can be submitted until the scholarship deadline date (typically January 15). If I choose not to submit my scores, how will that impact my ability/chances of receiving departmental scholarships? All students who apply to SMU and list an academic interest or major will be evaluated for departmental scholarships regardless of whether test scores are submitted or not. International Students I am an international student. Are you also waiving English proficiency requirements (e.g. TOEFL, IELTS, etc.)? Proof of English proficiency will still be required if your four years of high school education was not in English. Honors Programs If I do not submit test scores, will I be considered for the University’s honors programs? Yes, without standardized test scores, consideration for the University's honors program will still be given. Future Applicant - Entering SMU in 2023 and Beyond Will SMU consider going to test-optional in future years? At this time, SMU is fully test-optional. If I graduate in 2023 but decide to wait a year to apply to SMU, will this policy still apply to me? If a gap year is desired, apply for admission under the current test-optional policy and, if admitted, request a gap year. How will you review the second semester of my junior year? This is a challenging, uncertain time and SMU will continue to provide a truly holistic review of your application. It is the hope that all applicants will stay actively engaged in their academics to prepare for future academic success as well as for standardized testing. If schools go to a Pass/Fail system of grading (or credit/no credit), how will SMU review this during the application process? Many schools have planned to take this approach. There are no penalties for any adjustment to grading methodology during this period of time. Kim Konkel Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Schools School Contacts Kim Konkel Kim Konkel School Contacts Kim Konkel Nyemike Okonkwo Preston Sanderson Susanna Yatsko Kim Konkel Assistant Dean Undergraduate Recruiting and Communications 214-768-2081 kkonkel@smu.edu Schedule a virtual 1:1 appointment with Kim. Dedman College of Humanities and Sciences Originally born in Michigan, Kim grew up in Orlando, Florida, and in 2009 moved to Dallas, which she is now proud to call home. Kim has over 11 years of experience in higher education, seven of which were spent in the Office of Admission at Rollins College in Winter Park, Florida. Ms. Konkel received her B.A. in Organizational Communication with a minor in Business from Rollins College. “Having gone to a liberal arts college, I strongly believe in the value of a liberal arts education. Students with a liberal arts degree are equipped with a broad knowledge that allows them to adapt quickly to changing environments, think critically, solve problems and communicate effectively. That’s what makes a well-rounded leader and what is valuable in today’s job market.” If you would like more information on Dedman College of Humanities and Sciences or have any questions, please feel free to contact Kim via email or phone. Come be part of our active community of dedicated educators, engaged students, enthusiastic faculty, staff, administrators and alumni. For inquiries about graduate programs offered through Dedman College of Humanities and Sciences, please click here. Nyemike Okonkwo Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Schools School Contacts Nyemike Okonkwo Nyemike Okonkwo School Contacts Kim Konkel Nyemike Okonkwo Preston Sanderson Susanna Yatsko Nyemike Okonkwo Undergraduate Recruiter 7214-768-5496 nokonkwo@smu.edu Dedman College of Humanities & Sciences Nyemike is a native Texan who was born and raised in the north Dallas suburb of Plano, which is where he and his family now reside. After earning a B.A. in Interdisciplinary Studies from The University of Texas at Dallas, Nyemike taught elementary school math but always had thoughts of pursuing a career in higher education. Reflecting on his experience as an undergraduate and thinking of the needs of today’s student, Nyemike is excited to enhance his career in higher education and become an integral part of the support system for every Mustang. He is thrilled to share the endless possibilities of SMU’s Dedman College with prospective students and their families. Our faculty does more than teach. As a community of world-renowned scholars, they inform, challenge and transform academia. When you enter their classrooms, you enter into a partnership of learning that opens up whole new vistas of knowledge and lifelong learning. Almost all SMU faculty members hold doctorate degrees or the highest degrees in their fields. That means the people teaching your classes and leading your classroom discussions also are breaking new ground in their fields. We have science and engineering professors who hold patents on innovations that are making an impact on health care and technology. We have business and communications professors who are active consultants and entrepreneurs. We have arts faculty who compose, choreograph and create. And with our small class sizes, you'll get to know these groundbreakers personally, both inside the classroom and individually as your advisors and mentors. From libraries to computer centers, tutors to self-teaching materials, all kinds of support options are available to help you make the most of your education. The Altshuler Learning Enhancement Center is one of the most popular spots on campus. From “drop-in” tutoring to writing strategies and study skills workshops, you’ll learn how to maximize your study time and minimize your worries. Stop by Academic Advising for person-to-person guidance and a computerized, individual Degree Progress Report that can help map out your course. Academic Advising Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Academics Support and Resources Academic Advising Academic Advising Support and Resources Academic Advising A-LEC Career Center Corporations Internships Libraries Museums Networking Chart your college career SMU's University Advising Center can help with your academic planning from your first term toward graduation. Even if you know exactly which major you want to pursue, it's important to formulate a plan to build your academic portfolio and meet all of the requirements toward your degree. As a first-year student, you'll be assigned a professional advisor to help you map out an academic program that meets your individual goals. Once you declare a major, you'll be assigned an advisor in your academic field – yet another opportunity for a mentoring relationship. SMU was one of the first universities in the United States to establish a computerized degree audit system as part of our commitment to help keep you on track toward graduation. That way, we can help you take steps to correct your path if necessary. And we monitor your progress along the way. We also provide early progress reports in your first academic term, so that we can help you make necessary adjustments in study skills, learning style, or courses. We will work to help you get on track from the start. A-LEC Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Academics Support and Resources A-LEC A-LEC Support and Resources Academic Advising A-LEC Career Center Corporations Internships Libraries Museums Networking Grades up, stress down The Altshuler Learning Enhancement Center is one of the busiest, most popular student resources on campus. Using this center is a great way to keep grades up and stress levels down. SMU offers free tutoring services for many courses to any full-time undergraduate on a drop-in basis. Writing Center Strong writing skills are at the core of any rigorous education. Writing is essential not just for success in college, but for life. Through the Writing Center, you can improve your writing skills by meeting with a faculty member to discuss writing strategies or to review drafts of your papers. You'll receive personal attention from experts who will share practical pointers to refine your writing skills in any subject. Learning Skills Course HDEV 1210: Academic Success and Personal Development is a two-credit graded course designed to help students improve reading efficiency, executive functioning, and lifelong learning skills. Services cover everything from career counseling, assessment, and résumé writing to placement in internships, which can be paid or unpaid and some offer academic credit. The Career Center hosts a variety of specialized career fairs for business and technology, nonprofit opportunities, advertising, communications, and the liberal arts and sciences. SMU students also have access to job opportunities nationwide, thanks to regular campus visits by companies like American Airlines, Eli Lilly and Company and the top management accounting firms. And the Office of Alumni Relations offers an Alumni Career Network to connect students with SMU’s active and engaged alumni across the nation. Corporations Skip to main content SMU Explore SMU Academics Student Affairs About SMU News Events Calendar Research George W. Bush Presidential Center Current Students Alumni Information for Faculty & Staff Apply to SMUGIVE NOW Undergraduate Admission Apply Visit Financial Aid Menu Search Academics Support and Resources Corporations Corporations Support and Resources Academic Advising A-LEC Career Center Corporations Internships Libraries Museums Networking Entrepreneurial. Artistic. Dynamic. Yours. At SMU in Dallas, you get the best of both worlds – a spacious, tree-lined campus in a residential neighborhood surrounded by a bustling Metroplex bursting with opportunities for inspiration, exploration and recreation. Dallas as a center of commerce is well known. It’s the hub of the country’s fastest-growing private companies, home to the country's top Fortune 500 companies, and it consistently ranks among the top in the nation for its favorable business climate. More than big business, Dallas is also a center of culture and the arts, housing the nation's largest urban arts complex. It’s a nexus for the communications industry, ranging from film production to telecom technology, and includes a vast network of health care professionals and institutions. Dallas has been named one of the 10 most livable big cities in the region by Money magazine, and the reasons are numerous. Attending school in a fabulous location is only half of the picture. The portrait is complete when college links with community to broaden your education. Dynamic Dallas will enrich your educational experience at SMU.
